Powder X-ray diffraction patterns and thermal analyses of compounds 1 and 2


The phase purities of bulk samples of compounds 1 and 2 have been confirmed by the powder X-ray diffraction analyses. As shown in 

, the major peak positions of the bulk solids of compounds 1 and 2 match well with those of the simulated patterns based on respective single crystal X-ray diffraction data, indicating that the synthesized compounds are in pure phase. In addition, the thermal behaviors of compounds 1 and 2 were also investigated by thermalgravimetric analysis (TGA) under N2 atmosphere in the temperature range of 30–800 °C. For compound 1, there is no obvious weight loss in the temperature range of 30–270 °C, and after 270 °C, the framework started to collapse accompanied by the decomposition of the organic components. The residue of the powder may be ZnO (obsd: 24.98%, calcd: 24.18%) (c). For compound 2, the weight loss corresponding to the departure of the lattice water molecule is observed from to (obsd: 2.72%, calcd: 2.92%). The framework can be stable up to 271 °C, where the framework begins to collapse owing to the decomposition of the organic ligands. Finally, the remnants are 27.52%, corresponding to the formation of ZnO (calcd: 26.24%) (d) (see ).

Photoluminescent properties of compounds 1 and 2\n

Metal-organic frameworks with d10 transition metal ions have\u00a0attracted intense interest from chemists owing to their potential applications in photochemistry, chemical sensors, and electroluminescent displays . In this work, the luminescent properties of compounds 1 and 2 as well as the free ligands (H3bpt, H4bptc and Hdatrz) were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. The free H3bpt, H4bptc and Hdatrz ligands display intense emission peaks at 388\u00a0nm (\u03bbex\u00a0=\u00a0345\u00a0nm), 402\u00a0nm (\u03bbex\u00a0=\u00a0345\u00a0nm), 435\u00a0nm (\u03bbex\u00a0=\u00a0340\u00a0nm), respectively, which can be assigned to the \u03c0*-n or \u03c0*-\u03c0 transitions (b). Under the excitation light of 340\u00a0nm, compounds 1 and 2 show broad emission bands centered at 442\u00a0nm and 445\u00a0nm, respectively (a). Notably, the luminescent emission peaks of compounds 1 and 2 are similar to that of free Hdatrz ligand with red-shifts of 7\u00a0nm and 10\u00a0nm, respectively. The absence of the carboxylate-based ligands (H3bpt and H4bptc) emission bands further indicates that the luminescence of compounds 1 and 2 can be attributed to Hdatrz intraligand charge transfer .

Abstract

Three new metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), [Zn2(TZI)(μ
3-OH)(H2O)2]·(CH3)2NH (JUC-165), [Cd5(TZI)3(μ
3-OH)(H2O)7]·4H2O (JUC-166), and [Cd(TZI)]·(CH3)2NH2·H2O (JUC-167) (JUC=Jilin University China) have been synthesized by self-assembly of Zn2+/Cd2+ ions and a prominent ligand, 5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid (H3TZI). JUC-165 exhibits fascinating three-dimensional (3D) structure containing 1D rectangular channels with dimensions of 6.5×3.0Å2 and it performs (5,5)-connected topology with a Schläfli symbol of 4664, JUC-166 displays a 2D sandwich-layer which further forms into a 3D supermolecular structure by H-bonds reactions and JUC-167 exhibits (4,4)-connected 3D frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 42638. Furthermore, we research the fluorescence properties of these new MOFs measured at room temperature, and the results reveal that JUC-165, JUC-166 and JUC-167 display strong main emission spectra peaks at 410, 437 and 415nm, respectively.

Inspired by the aforementioned above, we opted to use the 5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid (H3TZI) ligand to coordinate with Zn2+ or Cd2+ ions and explore its potential in directing the assembly of extended frameworks based on its flexibility. Successfully, three new MOFs, [Zn2(TZI)(\u03bc\n3-OH)(H2O)2]\u00b7(CH3)2NH (JUC-165), [Cd5(TZI)3(\u03bc\n3-OH)(H2O)7]\u00b74H2O (JUC-166) as well as [Cd(TZI)]\u00b7(CH3)2NH2\u00b7H2O (JUC-167) were constructed. It\u2019s notable that for the rotation and bending of the mixed motifs in the ligand, H3TZI behaved various coordination modes and different configurations in the three structures. JUC-165 featured 3D frameworks including 1D rectangular channels with dimensions of 6.5\u00d73.0\u00c52, which performed (5,5)-connected frameworks with a Schl\u00e4fli symbol of 4664, JUC-166 performed 2D sandwich-layer which further form to 3D supermolecular structure by H-bonds reactions, JUC-167 exhibited 3D frameworks with a Schl\u00e4fli symbol of 42638. Moreover, we describe the luminescence properties of the three MOFs materials measured at room temperature and the results reveal strong main emission spectrum peaks at 410, 437 and 415nm of JUC-165, JUC-166 and JUC-167, respectively.

Results and discussion

Description of the crystal structure of JUC-165


Single crystal X-ray diffraction of JUC-165 reveals that it crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Cmcm. The asymmetric unit contains 0.5 Zn2+ cations, 0.25 TZI3− ligand, 0.25 μ
3-OH and 0.5 coordinated water molecular (). And the 0.25 (CH3)2NH of guest comes from the hydrolysis of DMF under high pressure and temperature . TZI3− ligand coordinates with six mental sites by the coordination mode which can be described as μ
6-η1: η0: η0: η1: η1: η1: η1: η1 (
a). Its conformation is mode-b by the dihedral is 90.0° between the m-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazolyl ring (). Two kinds of zinc centers (Zn1 and Zn2) are found in the framework. The Zn1 atom is five-coordinated by three oxygen atoms which consist of two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two TZI3− and one bridging oxygen atom from a μ
3-OH ligand in the equatorial plane, and two nitrogen atoms from two TZI3− ligands distribution in the axial position, which forms triangle biconical ZnN2O3 coordination geometry. While the Zn2 atom is six coordinate by four oxygen atoms from two μ
3-OH ligands, two coordinated water molecules and two nitrogen atoms from two different TZI3− ligands, forming an octahedral geometry. The Zn–O bond distances are from 1.962(4) to 2.128(6)Å, and the Zn–N bond distances are 2.110(5) and 2.362(5)Å (). For the interactions between metal sites and ligands described above, triangle [Zn3(μ
3-OH)] SBU are formed by μ
3-OH connecting three metal centers (b), these isosceles triangles connected by TZI3− spacers to form 1D strip-shaped chains further. Adjacent chains linked by m-benzenedicarboxylate groups to form 3D frameworks with 1D rectangular channels (6.5×3.0Å2) with taking van der Waals radii into consideration run along the c axis (c). A better insight into the nature of JUC-165 can be achieved by the application of a topological approach, that is, reducing multidimensional structures to simple node-and-linker nets (the Topos4.0 program is a powerful tool for the analysis, comparison, and design of network structures) . As shown in , the trimetallic [Zn3(μ
3-OH)] SBU can simply be regarded as a 5-connected node since the terminal H2O molecules do not contribute to the network topology. Likewise, each TZI3− ligand coordinated to five [Zn3(μ
3-OH)] clusters can act as a 5-connected node. On the basis of the simplification principle, the resulting structure of JUC-165 is a rare binodal five-connected net, and its Schläfli symbol is 4664 (d).

Description of the crystal structure of JUC-166


Single crystal X-ray diffraction of JUC-166 reveals that it crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group P212121. The asymmetric unit contains five Cd2+ cations, three TZI3−anion, one μ
3-OH and seven terminal coordinated water molecular (). For the TZI3− ligand, three kind of coordination modes were found which can be described as μ5
-η1: η0: η1: η1: η1: η1: η1 η0 (type (I)), μ5
-η1: η1: η1: η1: η1: η1: η1: η0 (type (II)), and μ
7-η0: η1: η2: η2: η1: η1: η0: η1 (type (III)), respectively (
a and b). It is worth noting that the dihedral between the m-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazolyl ring is 58.8°, 45.5°, and 2.2° of the three modes, respectively (). In this structure, there are five kinds of Cd2+ sites. Among them, Cd1, Cd2, Cd3, Cd5 are all six-coordinated octahedral geometry. For Cd1, it is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from two terminal coordinated waters and one bridging oxygen μ
3-OH ligand, and three nitrogen atoms from three TZI3− ligands. The Cd2 atom is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from one μ
3-OH ligands, two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two TZI3− ligands and three nitrogen atoms from three different TZI3− ligands. Cd3 atom is coordinated by five oxygen atoms from one TZI3− ligand, three terminal coordinated waters and one μ
3-OH ligand, and one nitrogen atom from one TZI3− ligand. For Cd5, it is six-coordinated by four oxygen atoms of three TZI3−, one terminal coordinated water oxygen atom, and one nitrogen atom from TZI3− ligand. While the Cd4 is seven-coordinated which consist of five carboxylate oxygen atoms from three TZI3−, one terminal coordinated water oxygen atom, and one nitrogen atom from TZI3− ligand, forming a single-cap triangular prism geometry. The Cd–O bond distances are from 2.267(8) to 2.567(7)Å, and the Cd–N bond distances are 2.346(8) and 2.457(7)Å (). The type (I) and type (II) linkers connect Cd1, Cd2, Cd4 and Cd5 centers to form two different 2D layers which are in the top and bottom, respectively. The two layers are like twins for they are very similar which form to a double-layer by sharing Cd1, Cd2 centers (c). In addition, the type (III) linkers as well as μ
3-OH ligand connect Cd1, Cd2, Cd3 and Cd4 centers to form another layer in the middle (d). And the intermediate layer is like a mirror which is caught in the middle of the twins-like layers (). Thus, the three monolayers form an overall sandwich-like 2D layer by sharing Cd1, Cd2, Cd4 and Cd5 centers. As we know, the sandwich-like tri-layer structure is rare . There are strong hydrogen bonding interactions (O6W–H⋯O1, O6W–H⋯O3 and O7W–H···O7 distance of 2.9350, 2.9136 and 2.7421Å, respectively ()) between adjacent 2D layers. The layers stack each other to form 3D supramolecular frameworks further (e).

Graphical abstract

The 3-D network compounds [NiCl2(pip)] (1) and [Cu2I2(pip)] (2) have been reported, which constructed from 1-D zigzag NiCl2 chains and 1-D merlon-like CuI double chains bridged by pip molecules, respectively. Compound 1 shows ferromagnetic property, while compound 2 possesses fluorescent property with an emission at 567nm.

Abstract

By the simple hydro/solvothermal reaction, two new 3-D metal\u2013halo cluster polymers, [NiCl2(pip)] (pip=piperazine) (1) and [Cu2I2(pip)] (2) were obtained and characterized by IR spectroscopy, CHN analysis and TG analysis. Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that, the 3-D network of compounds 1 and 2 are constructed from the 1-D zigzag NiCl2 chains and the 1-D castellated Cu2I2 chains bridged by pip molecules respectively. The \u03bceff versus T curve indicates that compound 1 is ferromagnetic when T\n>14K. The photoluminscent spectrum shows that compound 2 possesses the fluorescent property with a broad emission peak at 567nm upon excision at 397nm.

TG analysis

Thermogravimetric (TG) behavior was investigated on a SHIMADZU DTG-60 instrument in a temperature range of 25\u2013800\u00b0C with a heating rate of 10\u00b0Cmin\u22121 in air. As shown in \n, compound 1 exhibits one-step continuous weight-loss in the temperature range of 310\u2013575\u00b0C. The final residue is proved to be NiO (calc.: 34.62%; found: 33.15%), which suggests that the pip molecule and the Cl\u2212 ion released simultaneously, meanwhile, the Ni(II) ion combined with the O2 to form the NiO. Compound 2 underwent two steps of the weight loss. The first step from 210\u00b0C to 440\u00b0C should correspond to the loss of the pip, meanwhile, part Cu(I) transformed into CuO (calc.: 18.43%; found: 12.67%). The second stage should correspond to the sublimation of the I- ion and the oxidation of the residual Cu(I) (calc.: 54%; found: 51%).

Magnetic property

Magnetic susceptibility data were determined on the basis of a 10.3mg sample over the temperature of 2–300K at a magnetic field of 1 kG on a Quantum Design MPMS-7 SQUID magnetometer. The μeff versus T plot is shown in 
 (left) [μeff
=2.83 (χ
M
T)1/2]. The experimental μeff value at 300 K is 3.11μB, comparable with the theoretically expected value of 2.83μB for a d8 Ni(II) ion with an octahedral geometry. Upon cooling down, μeff increases continuously up to a maximum of 4.8μB at 14K, then drops rapidly down to a value of 1.4μB at 2 K. The 1/χ
M versus T curve is close to be linear when T
>150K [see  (right)], being well fitted by using the Curie Weiss law with C
=1.014emuKmol−1, and θ
=53.97K. On the other hand, zero-field splitting is known to occur for Ni(II) ions, and for isolated ions may induce either an increase or a decrease of μeff value at rather low temperature due to the site distortion of metal ion. Based on both stated above, the observed behavior is thus characteristic of the occurrence of ferromagnetic interactions within the NiCl2 chains due to a plus θ value, whereas the drop below 14K can be related to antiferromagnetic coupling between the chains as well as the effect of zero-field splitting. A 1-D chain model was used to fit the magnetic data of compound 1, unluckily no ideal result was obtained .

Photoluminescent property

The photoluminescent spectrum of compound 2 was measured on a LS 55 florescence/phosphorescence in the solid state at room temperature. As displayed in \n, the emission spectrum of compound 2 shows a strong band at 567nm with a shoulder at 593nm when excited at 397nm. The emission may be from a triplet \u201ccluster centered\u201d (3CC\u2217) excited state, which should be assigned to a combination of iodide to copper charge transfer (IMCT\u2217) and \u201cmetal cluster centered\u201d [(3MCC\u2217), dCu\n\u2192(s,p)Cu] transition. The weak Cu\u22efCu interactions with an average distance of 2.75\u00c5 within the Cu2I2 chain, as literature reported, will be responsible for a 3MCC\u2217 excited solid .

Compound 1, whose absorption spectrum is depicted in Kubelka Munk units in \n (black trace), is a dual luminescent material. Upon irradiation with \u03bb\n<300nm, a strong and narrow band, confined in the UV region, appears. If 1 is excited by wavelengths longer than 300nm, a broad band, included between 400 and 800nm, emerges (see ). The latter emission, located at lower energy is due to the bispiperidine diphosphonate ligand, since it is detectable also in the pure bispiperidine diphosphonic solid phase. The other emission, recorded only for 1, is most likely due to a charge transfer (CT) transition from the oxygen atoms of ligands to the Ce4+ ions; Ce3+ ions are produced that relax by emitting UV radiation. The CT nature of the transition is implicitly confirmed by the large Stokes shift (7138cm\u22121) and the FWHM of the emission band (3480cm\u22121) . It gives rise to a peaked band centered at 272nm, as inferred from the shape of the excitation spectrum (blue dashed trace of ).

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of JUC-188 was measured at room temperature. The characteristic peaks of the as-synthesized sample are closely matched well with those in the simulated patterns from the single crystal structure (a). The results confirmed the phase purity of the as-synthesized bulk crystalline materials. From the thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) results, the as-synthesized JUC-188 showed a gradual weight loss before 200\u00b0C about 19.78%, corresponding to the loss of one [H2N(CH3)2] cation, two coordinated water and four DMF guest molecules (calculated 19.44%) (b). The main framework of JUC-188 began to collapse with the increasing of heating temperature. The as-synthesized samples were exchanged with MeOH about three days, and activated at room temperature to obtain the activated samples. However, the activated samples didn't have any N2 adsorption, which was mainly ascribed to the collapse of the skeletal structure after removing the solvent molecules (Fig. S2). In addition, the PXRD pattern further indicated that the main framework of the activated samples was collapsed (Fig. S3). As shown in Fig. S4, the characteristic peaks of adenine and H4L ligands were both found in the FT-IR spectrum of JUC-188, which undoubtedly exhibited that both organic ligands coexisted in JUC-188.

Synthesis of the complexes

Synthesis of [{Ca(H2O)6}{CaLn(oda)3}2]\u00b74H2O

(Ln=Y (1), Eu (2), Tb (3), Ho (4), Er (5), Yb (6)). CaCl2\u00b72H2O (0.11g, 0.75mmol) and LnCl3\u00b76H2O (0.50mmol) were dissolved in 10mL of water. 2,2-Oxydiacetic acid (0.20g, 1.5mmol) were dissolved in another 10mL of water, and the pH value was adjusted to 7.0 with ammonium hydroxide. Both solutions were mixed, and a clear solution was obtained. The solution was allowed to evaporate slowly at room temperature. After some weeks, cubic crystals were obtained. Yield 30\u201350%. Anal. Calc. for C24H44O40Ca3Ln2: C, 22.7; H, 3.5 (1); C, 20.6; H, 3.2 (2); 20.4; H, 3.1 (3); 20.2; H, 3.1 (4); 20.2; H, 3.1 (5); 20.0; H, 3.1 (6). TGA diagrams show a single weight loss between room temperature and 200\u00b0C, corresponding to all water molecules (Fig. S1). Anal. Synthesis of [{Ca(H2O)6}{CaLn(oda)3}2]\u00b74H2O

(Ln=Dy (7), Tm (8), Lu (9). The mixture of Ln2O3 (0.10mmol) CaCl2\u00b72H2O (44mg, 0.30mmol) and 2,2-oxydiacetic acid (80mg, 0.60mmol) in 15mL of water was placed in a Teflon-lined 45mL stainless steel acid digestion vessel and heated at 120\u00b0C for 2days. The resulting clear solution was allowed to evaporate at room temperature. After some weeks, cubic crystals were obtained. Yield 30\u201350%. Anal. Calc. for C24H44O40Ca3Ln2: C, 20.3; H, 3.1 (7); C, 20.1; H, 3.1 (8), C, 20.0; H, 3.1 (9). Found: C, 20.4; H, 3.3 (7); C, 20.3; H, 2.9 (8), C, 20.1; H, 2.9 (9)%. TGA diagrams show a single weight loss between room temperature and 200\u00b0C, corresponding to all water molecules. Anal. Calc.: 12.7 (7); 12.6 (8), 12.5 (9). Found: 13.3 (7); 12.4 (8), 11.7 (9)%. Decomposition point, ca. 250\u00b0C.

Inspection of the 3D network (\n) reveals a pattern of cobalt and phenylene rings that emulates the sodium chloride lattice, with the cobalt atoms forming a face-centred cubic array (cf. Na) and with the centres of the ligand phenylene rings being positioned at the unit cell centre and at the centre of each of the 12 edges (cf. Cl) (\n). The shortest transannular Co\u22efCo distance within this network is 12.98 \u00c5. The network contains cavities of approximately 6 \u00c5 in diameter linked by channels with \u2018window\u2019 diameters of approximately 4 \u00c5. These cavities and channels contain the tetrafluoroborate anions and solvent methanol and water molecules, though these are all disordered and randomly displaced throughout the network, no discrete positions being identified.

Every Zn-trimer interconnects three Zn-trimers through one pair of FDAs in two modes: one pair of \u03bc4-\u03b72, \u03b71, \u03b71, \u03b71- FDAs (top in b) and one pair of \u03bc4-\u03b71, \u03b71, \u03b71, \u03b71- FDAs (bottom in b), which gives the (6,3) net (c). It is worth noting that two furan rings of two \u03bc4-\u03b72, \u03b71, \u03b71, \u03b71- FDAs (top in b) occupy the opposite positions with \u03c0\u2013\u03c0 conjugation, in which stacking h (center-plane) is in 3.276~3.290\u00c5, d(center-center) in 3.4645~3.367\u00c5 and shift r (displacement of two centers) in 1.1272~0.7159\u00c5. However, two furan rings of \u03bc4-\u03b71, \u03b71, \u03b71, \u03b71- FDAs (bottom in b) depart head-to-head from each other with the distance of two oxygens being 4.7954\u00c5. This is owing to \u03b72-O of \u03bc4-\u03b72, \u03b71, \u03b71, \u03b71- FDAs (top in b) which shortens the distance between furan rings. The dihedral angles of three furan rings is close to 120\u00b0 (dihedral angle of two furan rings of two \u03bc4-\u03b72, \u03b71, \u03b71, \u03b71- FDAs in 111.6\u00b0, two furan rings of \u03bc4-\u03b72, \u03b71, \u03b71, \u03b71- FDA and \u03bc4-\u03b71, \u03b71, \u03b71, \u03b71- FDA in 117.1\u00b0 and 113.3\u00b0, which promotes the formation of (6,3) net. The sheets are linked by bpp to 5-c bnn type topology with the Schl\u00e4fli symbol of (46\u00b764) (d). When the framework of MOF material is neutral and no balanced ion exists in the channel, water molecule or solvent often occupy the channel by the H-bond or van der waals force. In this work, water molecule remains in the channel. With the removal of the water, large accessible void is 676.2\u01fa3 about 32.0% of the unit cell volume (2114.9\u01fa3).

The thermogravimetric analysis of 1 (in N2) shows a sharp weight loss ranging from 270\u00b0C to 450\u00b0C (52.3%) corresponding to decomposition of FDA and bpp (Fig. S7). This also exhibits the framework stability (only 4% weight loss from room temperature to 270\u00b0C assigned to the structural water). The thermogravimetric analysis of 2 (in N2) shows continuously two-step weight loss (gradual and sharp) ranging from 150\u00b0C to 450\u00b0C (62.8%) corresponding to decomposition of FDA and bipy, which indicates the structural unstability of compound 2 (Fig. S8).

The gas-storage of MOF is of very interest. In this work, the experiments of gas adsorptions (degassed at 200\u00b0C) indicate that 1 can adsorb CO2 instead of N2, which is attributed to the strong quadrupole interaction of CO2. The CO2 gas-sorption isotherms for compound 1 at 273K indicate that the BET and Langmuir surface area are calculated to be 234.1 and 262.4m2/g, and the median pore diameter calculated by H-K method is 4.6\u00c5. Compound 1 indicates the medium CO2 uptake about 1.65mmol/g (Fig. S10).

Two new three-dimensional (3D) porous metal-organic frameworks, [Ni(tpt)2/3(bpta)1/4(H2O)2(OH)]\u22c5solve (1) and [Cd(tpt)(H2bpta)]\u22c5solve (2) (tpt=2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine, H4bpta=(1,1'-biphenyl)-2,2',6,6'-tetracarboxylic acid) have been prepared, and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, IR spectra, PXRD, and TG analysis. The results show that complex 1 has a 3D bor network structure with 56.9% solvent-accessible volume, and 2 reveals a novol 3,5-coordinated chiral topology with vertex symbol (4.72)(43.62.74.8) and 52.5% accessible void in the structure. Moreover, gas adsorption properties of desolvated 1 and 2 were investigated.

Compound 1, [Ni(tpt)2/3(bpta)1/4(H2O)2(OH)]\u22c5solve (solve represent for the unidentifiable solvent molecules), was obtained by the reaction of H4bpta with tpt and Ni(NO3)2\n\u22c56H2O in hydrothermal condition\u00a0 and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction . Compound 1 crystallizes in the F-43c space group. In 1, tpt ligands and metal ions assembled into eight interpenetrating (10,3)-a networks which has been observed in Zn(tpt)2/3(SiF6)(H2O)2(MeOH) as reported by B.F. Abrahams et al. . However, the coordinated SiF6\n2- anion in the reported architecture was replaced with one dehydrogenized carboxyl from H4bpta, and the coordination sphere of the six coordinated Ni(II) center was accomplished with two water molecules and one hydroxyl group. The Ni\u2013O bond lengths vary from 2.049(3) to 2.088(3)\u00c5, and the Ni\u2013N bond lengths range from 2.093(2) to 2.108(3)\u00c5. Benefiting from its structure characteristic, each bpa4\u2212 joint two left- and two right-handed individual chiral (10,3)-a subnets together by coordinating to Ni(II) ions from the corresponding subnets. As the individual (10,3)-a subnets interconnected by bpa4- ligands, a complicated three dimensional porous framework was achieved. In the structural view, the discrete networks were banded together and the eight interpenetrating (10,3)-a topology was modified by the connectivity increased from the presenting of bpa4\u2212 ligands. To simplify and realize the structure of 1, bpa4\u2212 ligand could be viewed as four connected vertex and the stacking tpt ligands could be viewed as triangle building blocks (a), then the overall structure could be simplified into a network bearing bor topology (b). According to the topology of the framework, the free volume found in the framework of 1 could be divided into chambers and channels, separately. In the octahedron double-wall chambers raised from the connection of four triangle building blocks and six vertexes, the dimension between the opposite vertexes is about 21.3\u00c5 and the triangle window formed has 10.2\u00c5 length edge, slightly bigger than the similar reported coordination cage . The channels formed among the stacking vertex shared chambers has a diameter about 9.5\u00c5. The solvent-accessible volume of 1 calculated using the PLATON  was 56.9% (44,468.4\u00c53 out of the 78,200.0\u00c53 unit cell volume). This value is comparable to that found in some of the most open zeolites, such as faujasite in which the free space is 45-50% of the crystal volume.

Compound 2, [Cd(tpt)(H2bpta)]\u22c5solve, was obtained by the solvothermal reaction of tpt, H4bpta and Cd(NO3)2\u22c54H2O in DMF and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction . In 2, the Cd(II) ions are seven coordinated by three nitrogen atoms from three tpt ligands, and four oxygen atoms from two carboxylate groups of two different H2bpta2- ligands with chelating mode. The Cd\u2013O bond lengths vary from 2.365(17) to 2.422(10)\u00c5, and the Cd\u2013N bond lengths range from 2.393(9) to 2.462(15)\u00c5. Ignoring the connectivity of H2bpta2\u2212, the subnet formed by Cd(II) ions and tpt ligands shows 3-coordinated uniform self-penetrating twt network topology . However, with the Cd(II) ions interconnected by H2bpta2\u2013, the whorl of separated helix chains assembled with Cd(II) ions and tpt ligands was supported and reinforced by the coordination of H2bpta2\u2212 with Cd(II) (a) to form a single triple-helix chain. The topology of 2 can be explained as follows. The Cd(II) ions could be simplified as five connected nodes meanwhile the tpt ligands can be considered as three connected nodes. As a result, the original twt topology was modified into a non-reported 3,5-coordinated chiral topology (c) with vertex symbol (4.72)(43.62.74.8) . A void space analysis indicates that the solvent accessible void in the structure of 2 reaches 52.5% (2070.4\u00c53 out of the 3946.2\u00c53 unit cell volume).

Preliminary gas sorption studies were performed with activated 1 and 2 (
). The N2 sorption isotherm of both 1 and 2 shows type I gas sorption behavior indicative of microporous structure. The vacuum-dried sample of 1 exhibited a Langmuir surface area of 393m2
g−1 (a SABET of 299m2
g−1) whereas the sample of 2 gave a Langmuir surface area of 442m2
g−1 (a SABET of 336 m2g-1). Hydrogen adsorption isotherms measured at 77K reveal an uptake of 65cm3
g−1 at 800mmHg for 1. Similarly, 2 afford an uptake of 70cm3
g−1 at 800mmHg. Both uptakes of N2 and H2 are relatively low considering the highly porous nature of these MOFs materials, presumably because of the blockage of the cavity and channel in the activated sample accordingly to the change of structure during the activation process. Better results were expected by the enhancement of porosity using proper activating method .

X-ray single crystal diffraction data for 1 was collected on a Rigaku Saturn 70 diffractometer at 293(2) K with Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073Å) by ω scan mode, and diffraction data for 2 was collected on a Rigaku SCX-mini diffractometer at 293(2)K with Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073Å) by ω scan mode. The program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All the structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL (semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using SADABS program). Metal atoms in each complex were located from the E-maps. Other non-hydrogen atoms in 1 were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses and refined with anisotropic thermal parameters on F
2. The location of hydrogen atoms of coordinated water and hydroxy were not able to be assigend. Part of the non-hydrogen atoms in 2 were fixed at the theoretical sites and refined with isotropic thermal parameters together with the hydrogen atoms ride on. The hydrogen atoms of the ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. Free solvent molecules in both 1 and 2 were highly disordered, and attempts to locate and refine the solvent peaks were unsuccessful. The diffuse electron densities resulting from the these residual solvent molecules were removed from the data set using the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON and refined further using the data generated. The contents of the solvent region are not represented in the unit cell contents in crystal data. Attempts to determine the final formula of such compounds from the SQUEEZE results combined with elemental analysis and TGA data were also unsuccessful because of the volatility of solvents; therefore, an accurate data set could not be obtained. Results and discussion

Description of the crystal structure of 1\n

The result of X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that complex 1 crystallizes in high symmetry of cubic form with space group of Pn-3 and the asymmetric unit has a one-sixth Co(II) atom sitting on a special position with a one-sixth occupancy, half of the deprotonated L\u2212 ligand, solvent water molecules and methanol molecules. Every Co(II) center in the framework is octahedral coordinated. Considering the balance of the charge, the anionic charge of framework is balanced by a proton H+, which could not be located by X-ray diffraction, but are probably bound to the nucleophilic N atoms of imidazole rings, or one of the solvent water molecules was protonated. As shown in \na, each Co(II) atom is coordinated by six nitrogen atoms from six individual L\u2212 ligands with distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The Co\u2013N distance of 2.141(4)\u00c5 and N\u2013Co\u2013N bond angles of 91.77(1)\u00b0, 88.23(1)\u00b0 and 180\u00b0 are typical for the octahedral Co\u2013Nim coordinations . On the other hand, each L\u2212 ligand acts as a linear ligand to link two Co(II) atoms with a Co\u2013Co separation of 13.66\u00c5. It is noteworthy that only one of the two nitrogen atoms of the deprotonated imidazol-4-yl group coordinates with the Co(II) atom.

The connections of the octahedral node of the central Co(II) and linear linker of the L\u2212 ligand make 1 to form a 3D framework with large channels as illustrated in , and the topology can be described as crs net (\na) with the Schl\u00e4fli symbols of (36, 66, 73) . There is large void in the single net of 1 as mentioned above, and according to the famous Aristotle\u2019s observation that \u201cnature abhors a vacuum\u201d, interpenetration occurred inevitable. After careful inspecting the structure of 1, we found that there are two individual 3D crs nets interpenetrating with each other (b). It is noteworthy that there are still voids although the 2-fold interpenetration happened. The effective free volume of 1 calculated by PLATON analysis is 65.4% (4711.9\u00c53 per unit) filled by water molecules and methanol molecules .

The results of X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that complex 2 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/n (), its symmetry is far less than complex 1 which crystallizes in cubic space group. The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of a half of Co(II) atom, two-thirds of HL ligands, one coordinated water molecule, one solvent water molecule and a ClO4\n\u2212 ion. As displayed in \na, each Co(II) atom is six-coordinated by four nitrogen atoms from four different HL ligands and two oxygen atoms of water molecules. The Co\u2013O bond length is 2.095(2)\u00c5 and the Co\u2013N bond lengths are 2.145(2) and 2.147(2)\u00c5. The N(112)\u2013Co\u2013N(112A) and O(1)\u2013Co\u2013O(1A) bond angles are 180\u00b0, the other bond angles are in the range of 88.24(9)\u201391.76(9)\u00b0.

Description of crystal structure of 3\n

The HL can act as a natural ligand without deprotonation, and then we get complex 3. The complex 3 crystallizes in orthorhombic with space group of Pban and the asymmetric unit also has a quarter molecule of [Co(HL)2(H2O)2]Cl2, and there are coordinated water molecules and chloride counteranions in 3. As depicted in \na, the Co(II) center is coordinated by four nitrogen atoms from four different HL ligands with the Co\u2013N distance of 2.143(4)\u00c5 and two oxygen atoms of water molecules with Co\u2013O distance of 2.112(6)\u00c5. Therefore, the coordination geometry of the Co(II) center can be regarded as a lengthened octahedral with N4O2 binding set in which the equatorial plane is composed of four imidazole nitrogen atoms and two apical positions are occupied by two water molecules. The HL ligand also acts as a linear building block to link two Co(II) atoms with a Co\u2013Co distance of 13.91\u00c5. The connections of the central square-planar Co(II) (omitting two terminal water molecules) and linear linker of the HL ligand also make complex 3 to form a 3D framework with large channels (22.70\u00c5\u00d720.90\u00c5) (b). The topology can be described as dia net with the short and long Schl\u00e4fli symbols of 66 and (62.62.62.62.62.62), respectively . The whole structure of complex 3 is a 4-fold interpenetrated framework (c) due to a large void in the single net. It is noticeable that there is uncoordinated chloride counteranions filled in the void of the interpenetrated framework.

Gas sorption property

As we discussed above, the framework of 1 is stable even up to 290\u00b0C. Before gas adsorption tests, the activation for removing the guest molecules from the pores by heating in vacuum is a required pretreatment and the as-synthesized crystal samples were heated at an optimized temperature at 140\u00b0C for 20h. The N2 adsorption isotherm for 1 is shown in \n, approximately 22.0317cm3 (1.30mmol) of N2 per gram of solvent-free sample was adsorbed at 1atm with a pore volume of 0.09cm3/g (median pore width is 6.61\u00c5), the sorption behavior is characteristic for the microporous structure .

Reported herein are two porous interpenetrated anionic Cd-carboxylate frameworks tuned by the length of organic linker. Shorter BDC linker and [Cd(COO)4] building blocks in 1 generate a rare 4-connected 2-fold interpenetrating qtz network. But longer NDC linker in 2 produces a self-penetrated 8-connected bcu framework with [Cd3(COO)8] SBUs. 1 and 2 both show selective CO2 adsorption and significantly, 2 exhibits the highest water vapor uptake performance (281cm3\u00b7g\u22121 at 298K and P/P0\n=0.95) among all the interpenetrated MOFs.

More recently, we report a 3-fold self-interpenetrated Zn-carboxylate MOF, which presents an unprecedented 1D channel partition via interpenetration into polyhedral cages . The unique structural feature contributed to not only the highest CO2 uptake capacity but also strongest CO2 affinity among the interpenetrated MOFs. As an extension of this work, we demonstrated herein two interpenetrated anionic Cd-carboxylate frameworks effectively tuned by the length of organic linkers, namely, {[(CH3)2NH2]2[Cd(BDC)2]}

Colorless hexagonal prism crystals of 1 were got in pure phase under the hydrothermal reaction of Cd(NO3)2\u00b74H2O and the most common ditopic carboxylic acid linker (BDC) . Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that MOF 1 is a 4-connected 2-fold interpenetrating qtz network crystallizing in the hexagonal P6(2)22 space group . The asymmetric unit of 1 contains part of a Cd atom on a site with crystallographic 222 symmetry and one half of a BDC ligand lying about a twofold axis. Each Cd center adopts triangulated dodecahedral geometries by the chelation of four carboxylate groups from four BDC anions (a). The Cd\u2013O bond lengths are in the range of 2.352(6)\u20132.476(7) \u00c5 and the O\u2013Cd\u2013O bond angles range from 52.1(2) to 165.8(4)\u00b0. If the carboxylate groups are considered as connecting points, carbon atoms around the Cd centers in 1 will show a highly distorted pseudo-tetrahedral geometry with the angles of C\u2013Cd\u2013C are 89.5(3), 100.8(4), and 145.2(3)\u00b0. Each Cd center connects to the other Cd centers by linear BDC bridges to produce a quartz network (qtz) (b). Twofold interpenetration is observed in the structure of MOF 1, in which the pseudotetrahedron centers in one net occupy on the center of the 6-ring in another network, and the four arms of tetrahedron are interpenetrated through 6-ring each other in the up\u2013down\u2013up\u2013down form (c,d). 1D channel exists along the c-axis direction, which is occupied by the disordered [(CH3)2NH2]+ to balance the charge of anionic Cd-BDC framework of 1.

Under the similar reaction conditions, the utilization of longer ditopic carboxylic acid linker (NDC) instead of BDC led to the formation of yellow block crystals of MOF 2\n. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction study shows that compound 2 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Fdd2 space group . The asymmetric unit contains three unique Cd(II) atoms and four independent NDC ligands. As depicted in a, three Cd atoms all exhibit distorted octahedral configuration generated by six oxygen atoms from different NDC ligands. The Cd\u2013O bond lengths are in the range of 2.187(7)\u20132.528(7) \u00c5 and the O\u2013Cd\u2013O bond angles range from 52.6(3) to 179.4(4)\u00b0. Three independent Cd atoms are bridged by six carboxylate groups from six different NDC ligands to form a linear trinuclear cluster with Cd3 as the symmetrical center. Cd1 and Cd2 further coordinate to one terminal chelating carboxlate group from another NDC. Overall, three Cd atoms link eight carbloxlate groups to give a [Cd3(COO)8]2\u2212 SBU. The Cd1\u2013Cd3 and Cd2\u2013Cd3 separations are of 3.4831(9) \u00c5 and 3.4658(10) \u00c5, respectively. The trinuclear cluster and NDC ligands link each other to form the 3D porous framework of MOF 2 (b). 1D irregular small channel is observed along the c-axis direction and occupied by the charge-balanced [(CH3)2NH2]+. Furthermore, the [Cd3(COO)8]2\u2212 SBU and NDC ligands can be regarded as 8-connected node and linker as depicted in c, which led an 8-connected net with a point symbol of {424\u00b764}. However, it should be pointed out that the 8-connected net of MOF 2 is different from the common bcu net, which exhibits a self-penetration as shown in d. To the best of our knowledge, this kind of self-penetrating bcu net is rarely reported up to date. The only example reported by Wang  had a 424\u00b75\u00b763 topology with the four-membered ring is penetrated, but in the network of 2, it is the six-membered ring. Clearly, the utilization of longer NDC linker effectively led to the transformation of mononuclear [Cd(COO)4] to trinuclear [Cd3(COO)8]2\u2212 SBU, which further introduced the formation of 8-connected bcu net of MOF 2 instead of 4-connected qtz net of MOF 1.

Notably, as mentioned above, penetrated Cd-carboxylate frameworks 1 and 2 both possess 1D channel along c-direction. PLATON calculations show that they have 61.8% and 48.6%, respectively, potential guest-accessible volumes. These prominent structure features provoke us to study their porosity. However, the N2 sorption isotherms at 77K indicate negligible uptakes for the MOFs 1 and 2 activated at 80\u00b0C, which is probably due to their small pore sizes introduced by the interpenetration and also blocked by the charge-balanced cations. It should be pointed out similar N2 uptake results had also been found in an iso-structure of MOF 2 obtained in DMF solvent . Furthermore, the porosity of these two MOFs was supported by the CO2 adsorption at 195K (Fig. S3a). The corresponding BET surface area is 372m2\ng\u22121 and 154m2\ng\u22121 for 1 and 2, respectively. It should be noted that compound 1 exhibits a pressure-dependent, stepwise CO2 adsorption\u2013desorption isotherms at 195K, which further support the dynamic twofold interpenetrating frameworks.

The low-pressure CO2 adsorption\u2013desorption isotherms were measured at 273K and 298K. Under 1bar, the CO2 uptakes at 273K reach 42cm3\u00b7g\u22121 (1.9mmol\u00b7g\u22121, 8.3wt.%) for MOF 1, and 24cm3\u00b7g\u22121 (1.1mmol\u00b7g\u22121, 4.7wt.%) for MOF 2 (a). At 298K and 1bar, MOFs 1 and 2 can absorb CO2 of 25cm3\u00b7g\u22121 (1.1mmol\u00b7g\u22121, 4.9wt.%) and 13cm3\u00b7g\u22121 (0.6mmol\u00b7g\u22121, 2.6wt.%). Although such CO2 adsorption capacity is not high, these values still outperform many previously reported interpenetrated MOFs such as SNU-71 , YO-MOF  and so on. Compared to the no-interpenetrated MOFs, the CO2 adsorption capacity of 1 is also higher than a lot of famous MOFs such as ZIF-8 , MOF-2 , SNU-31 , and ZIF-100  at 298K and 1atm. Clearly, take the negligible N2 adsorption into account, interpenetrated porous MOFs 1 and 2 exhibit dramatically selective CO2 uptake performance, which may be due to the small pore size introduced by interpenetration and the charged frameworks of 1 and 2.

The adsorption of water vapor by porous solids is important for many applications, such as dehumidification, thermal batteries, and requiring capture and release of water. More recently, MOFs have been demonstrated to be promising water vapor adsorption materials . Herein, we further show that high and steep water vapor uptake at low relative pressure can be achieved by our interpenetrated Cd-NDC MOF 2. The water vapor adsorption isotherm of compound 2 is shown in b. Notably, the maximum water uptake at 298K reaches 281cm3·g−1 under P/P
0
=0.95 (where P
0 is the vapor pressure at saturation). The maximum water uptake of MOF 2 is comparable to the values of Basolite A100  and another cadmium(II) MOF  reported by D. F. Li, which are 250cm3·g−1 and 249cm3·g−1, respectively, Significantly, this value is much higher than a lot of MOF material, including CAU-10 functionalised by –NO2, −NH2, −CH3 and –OCH3 groups , DUT-84 (Zr) , and Fe-MOFs reported by Tapas Kumar Maji . To the best of our knowledge, the water vapor adsorption capacity of MOF 2 at 298K outperforms all previously reported interpenetrated MOFs.

As shown by the TG curves (), all obtained MAFs are stable up to at least 400\u00b0C, except that MAF-7 decomposed just above 300\u00b0C. It should be noted that there is virtually no observable weight loss below the decomposition temperatures, indicating that the as-synthesized powder samples of porous MAFs can be easily activated by routine drying procedures, which is a remarkable improvement as compared to the common solvothermal methods using amides as solvents . Thermal stabilities of the porous MAFs were further checked by variable-temperature PXRD analyses, which revealed that MAF-7 collapsed above 170\u00b0C (), being much lower than for MAF-4 and MAF-5 (>400\u00b0C) .

Different from the \u03bc-N1,N2- and \u03bc-N1,N4-bridging modes in 1 and 2, the deprotonated datrz\u2212 anion in 3 adopts a \u03bc3-N1,N2,N4-binding mode to aggregate pairs of symmetry-related CoII ions (Co1 and Co1A, as well as Co2 and Co2B) into a bimetallic {Co2(datrz)2}2+ dimer through N1 and N2 sites and further extend the dimeric subunits through the N4 position (b). Notably, two unique {Co2(datrz)2}2+ subunits are perpendicular to each other, generating a wavy 2D layer with (4, 82) topology on the crystallographic ac plane. The nearest CoII\u22efCoII separations generated by two unique \u03bc3-N1,N2,N4-datrz\u2212 ligands are 3.72\u20136.13\u01fa (b), implying a corner-sharing triangular magnetic lattice with lower symmetry. Each undulated layer of 3 is periodically pillared by the two crystallographically independent, mirror-symmetric CH3-ip2\u2212 pillars in the same bis-monodentate binding mode, generating a 3D microporous pillared-layer framework of 3 with the interlayer intermetallic distance of 10.2565(22) and 10.2592(22)\u00c5, respectively (c). A calculation with PLATON reveals that the total potential solvent area is 1395.2\u00c53, in which the volume of each unit cell is 4660.9\u00c53.

PXRD and thermal stability of 1\u20134\n

Experimental and computer-simulated PXRD patterns of the four bulk products were in good agreement with each other (), indicating their phase purity and the structural consistency as the synthesized samples. TG experiments of 1\u20134 were carried out in order to explore their thermal stability (). As a result, complex 1 displayed a slight weight-loss process between 60 and 145\u00b0C for the release of the lattice water molecule, and was followed by a rapid weight-loss stage between 376 and 550\u00b0C for the decomposition of the layered structure. The remaining residue of 1 was calculated to be CoO above 550\u00b0C (expt. 25.5%, calc. 25.7%). Complex 2 exhibited one continuous weight-loss process above 100\u00b0C, corresponding to the continuous removal of methanol and the combustion of the mixed ligands. The final product of 2 above 445\u00b0C was calculated to be CoO (expt. 21.6%, calc. 20.4%). Complex 3 showed a two-step weight-loss stage between 60 and 180\u00b0C for the slow release of disordered lattice molecules (expt. 8.3%, calc. 8.4%). Once the temperature was higher than 427\u00b0C, the polymeric backbone collapse of 3 occurred, which was completely finished at the highest temperature measured. Complex 4 was thermally stable up to 241\u00b0C, and was accompanied by a continuous weight-loss process between 241\u00b0C and 315\u00b0C for the remove of lattice water molecule (expt. 6.1%, calc. 4.7%). The second obvious weight-loss stage between 370 and 533\u00b0C was resulting from the decomposition of the mixed ligands, leaving Co2O3 as final product of 4 (expt. 22.2%, calc. 21.6%).

Crystal structure of [Co(CH3OH)(Hdatrz)(CH3-ip)]n (2)

Complex 2 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Pna21 space group (), exhibiting a robust 3D framework with helical {Co(\u03bc-N1,N4-Hdatrz)}2+ chains interconnected by bidentate chelating-monodentate-CH3-ip2\u2212 linkers. The asymmetric unit of 2 contains one CoII ion, one neutral \u03bc-N1,N4-Hdatrz molecule, one doubly deprotonated CH3-ip2\u2212 anion and one terminally coordinated methanol molecule. As illustrated in \na, the sole CoII ion in 2 also adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry surrounded by two N and four O donors from two separate Hdatrz molecules, one terminal methanol molecule, two bidentate chelating and one monodentate carboxylate groups from two different CH3-ip2\u2212 anions. The bond lengths of Co\u2013O and Co\u2013N are comparable to those of 1 (). Adjacent CoII octahedra in 2 are periodically extended by \u03bc-N1,N4-Hdatrz ligands, generating a helical {Co(\u03bc-N1,N4-Hdatrz)}2+ chain running along the crystallographic a-axis with the intermetallic separation of 6.3070(1)\u00c5 (b). The intermetallic separation by \u03bc-N1,N4-Hdatrz is moderate longer by 2.63\u00c5 than that by \u03bc-N1,N2-Hdatrz in 1, being expected to transfer weak magnetic interaction. Furthermore, adjacent chains of 2 are crosslinked through bidentate chelating-monodentate-CH3-ip2\u2212 ligands, generating a robust 3D framework with the interchain CoII\u22efCoII separation of 8.2813(2) \u01fa (c).

Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of compounds 1\u20134 were investigated under the flowing nitrogen atmosphere (\n). Unusually, they exhibit two kinds of thermal behavior. The TG curves of 1 and 2 only show one platform from room temperature to 370\u00a0\u00b0C, then the ligand decomposition makes the whole framework totally collapse. In comparison, there are two obvious platforms in the TG plots of 3 and 4. For 3, The first weight loss of 24% from 280 to ca. 330\u00a0\u00b0C corresponds to the full liberation of e-urea molecules (calcd: 23.6%), and the remaining framework [Zn(ntd)]n shows no weight loss up to ca. 400\u00a0\u00b0C. The compared powder X-ray diffraction patterns further confirm that the framework [Zn(ntd)]n does not change at 300\u00a0\u00b0C, but it shifts to an unknown phase after full removal of the e-urea ligands at 350\u00a0\u00b0C (\n). The total solvent-accessible volume of 3 is estimated to be 34.9% using the PLATON program . The TGA curve of 4 is similar to that of 3, but 4 has higher thermal stability than 3. As demonstrated by the powder X-ray diffraction patterns, the framework of 4 does not change at 350\u00a0\u00b0C.

The CO2 gas adsorption measurements of 3 and 4 at 273\u00a0K performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and pore size analyzer were investigated, which further confirm the porosity in 3 and 4. Both samples of 3 and 4 were activated under vacuum at 300\u00a0\u00b0C for 2 days, respectively. A significant increase in the amount of CO2 gas adsorbed by each sample was observed as with an increase in the CO2 pressure (\n), indicating the diffusion of CO2 molecules into the channels. The CO2 uptake at 1\u00a0atm for 3 and 4 were 6.7\u00a0cm3/g and 13.6\u00a0cm3/g, respectively. The higher CO2 uptake capacity of 4 than that of 3 may be due to the higher framework stability of 4.

In compound 1, the Cu1 atoms and HPyImDC2\u2212 anions are arranged in a line to form 1D chains {-Cu-HPyImDC2\u2212-Cu-} along the [010] direction, which are further interconnected by the Cu2 atoms to build 1D rhombic chains along the [101] direction (a). The corner-sharing 1D chains are alternately linked together by Cu2 atoms in different directions to generate a 3D open framework (b), which displays rhombic openings with an approximate diameter of 13.7\u00d76.2\u00c5 (point-to-point and not including van der Waals radii) along [010] direction (c). The uncoordinated ammonium ions serve as guest molecules in the channels and are protonated in order to balance the negative charge provided by framework. Excluding the guest molecules, compound 1 has a 3898\u00c53 potential solvent volume estimated by PLATON , accounting for 35.2% of the total cell volume.

The thermal stabilities of compounds 1 and 2 are investigated through TGA experiments in the temperature range of 35\u2013800\u00b0C as shown in Fig. S7. An initial weight loss of compound 1 below 150\u00b0C can be attributed to the removal of N, N-dimethylformamide on the surface of the compounds. Upon further heating the organic ligand and the ammonium ions start to decompose and exhibit a weight loss of 73.30% between 165 and 393\u00b0C (calcd: 75.86%). The final product of 25.86% is attributed to the formation of CuO powder.

To study the stability of the three compounds, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on polycrystalline samples in nitrogen atmosphere. For 1, the weight loss of 4.08% from 160 to 279\u00b0C is equivalent to the loss of one free water molecule per formula unit (ca. 3.96%), indicating the presence of hydrogen bonding interactions. After 317\u00b0C, the decomposition of the framework starts. For 2, the thermogravimetric analysis shows that there is no weight loss up to 360\u00b0C, where the entirely decomposition of 2 starts. For 3, the weight loss of 6.78% (calculated: 6.61%) from 45 to 134\u00b0C, is attributed to the loss of two free water molecules per formula unit. Complete decomposition of the framework starts after 415\u00b0C.

Optical diffuse-reflection UV\u2013vis spectra were measured at room temperature using BaSO4 as a standard reference. The absorption spectra of the compounds were calculated from the data of diffuse-reflectance and are depicted in \n. Spectra of three C2 compounds are showed in (a). The intense broad bands at about 3.4\u00a0eV for 1 (Se) and 2 (Se) and 3.8\u00a0eV for 3 (S) with the onset energy about 2.85\u00a0eV for 1, 2 and 3.20\u00a0eV for 3 are assigned to the cluster-centered excitation, which indicates that the selenide has the narrower energy gap than that of the sulfide. The band at about 2.75\u00a0eV is assigned to the metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) absorption of the [Ru(Phen/Bpy)3]2+ cations , which is also the evidence of the presence of these cations in the compounds. The onset energy of the MLCT is about 2.1\u00a0eV, which extends the photo absorption to the visible range that significantly narrows the energy gaps of the materials. Based on the results of our previous studies, the shoulder peaks in above 2.9\u00a0eV are assigned to charge-transfer bands from cluster anion to [Ru(Phen/Bpy)3]2+ cation (ACCT) , which overlapped with the MLCT band. (b) shows the spectra difference of the C1 and C2 compounds with the same [Ru(Bpy)3]2+ cations. Comparing to C2 cluster, the onset energy 3.10\u00a0eV for C1 cluster 4 shifts to the blue side due to the decreased size of the cluster.

About thirteen C2 clusters have been reported up to date (.), but only three compounds are 3-D polymeric structure. The counterions of the 3-D compounds are all rigid complex cations of [M(Phen)3]2+ or [M(Bpy)3]2+ (M\u00a0=\u00a0Fe and Ru) . The others are low dimensional structures. In this work we obtained three new C2 chalcogenido clusters with complex cations of [Ru(Phen)3]2+ or [Ru(Bpy)3]2+ and they are all 3-D structures. From these results the templating effects of the [M(Phen/Bpy)3]2+ cations on the 3-D structure are obvious. The structure of 1 is constructed by two 3D inter-penetrated diamond frameworks in different symmetry that is shown in \n. The average corner-to-corner distance of the supertetrahedron is 19.24(2) \u00c5 (without considering the thiophenol group), and the center-to-center distance of the cluster is 22.205(3) \u00c5. Therefore, it is a 3-D matrix with homosized nano CdSe@CdS core\u2013shell particles (ac 2.0\u00a0nm). The structures of the other two compounds 2 and 3 are similar to 1, except that the Ru(Phen)3 is replaced by the Ru(Bpy)3 in 2 (C2/c space group) and the selenium ions are replaced by the sulfur ions in 3 (Fddd space group), .

In 1960s, Jørgensen noticed that the positions of the hypersensitive bands change with different compounds and proposed the “nephelauxetic” effect explaining this phenomenon . With the increasing of the overlap of the oxygen orbitals and the 4f orbitals (the nephelauxetic effect), the energy level structure of the lanthanide ion contracts and leads to a shift of hypersensitive bands towards longer wavelengths (the red shift). Such a shift was observed by us for the hypersensitive transition 6H5/2
→
6F5/2 (see 
). The size of the nephelauxetic effect can be characterized by ratio β calculated as follows: β
=1/nΣ(υav(complex)/υav(ion)), where n is the number of transitions observed, and υav is the average band position (cm−1) for the Sm3+ ion in LaF3
. This parameter may be regarded as a measure of the covalency of the Ln–O bond . For the present compound, β is 1.0005 and Sinha’s parameter σ, defined as σ
={|(1−β)/β|}·100, is 0.0523.  shows the comparison of these values for samarium(III) fumarate and samarium(III) maleate . It can be concluded that hence σ
mal
>
σ
fum, the Sm–O bonding is more covalent for maleate than fumarate. The average wavelength of the hypersensitive band of Sm3+ (6H5/2
→
6F1/2) is 5921cm−1 for maleate and 6250cm−1 for fumarate. The increase of the covalency of the Sm–O bonds is noticeable through the visible growth of the intensity of the hypersensitive transition when going from fumarate to maleate (see ). This relation between the increasing of covalency and the higher intensities of hypersensitive transitions has been postulated very often . This kind of relation is possible to compare in a simple way when the coordination number (C.N.=9) is the same for both systems (see ).

The reaction of 4,4′-bipyridine with CdSO4·8/3H2O in water in 1:1 mole ratio in a sealed tube at 120°C gave 1 as pure crystalline product in 57% yield. A sample of 256 mg (1.0 mmol) CdSO4·8/3H2O and 156 mg (1.0 mmol) 4,4′-bipyridine was mixed thoroughly and loaded into a thick-walled Pyrex tube. After ∼1.0 ml H2O was added, the tube was frozen with liquid N2, evacuated under vacuum and sealed with a flame. The reaction was carried out at 120°C for 24 h to afford colorless single crystals of 1. The product was isolated by acetone washing in 57% yield. The compound is insoluble in common organic solvents such as THF, acetone, CH2Cl2, and CH3CN or water. The single crystal X-ray structure analysis showed that 1 crystallizes in the C-centered, noncentrosymmetric space group C2 (No. 5). Crystallographic data for 1, C20H28Cd2N4O14S2, monoclinic C2 (No. 5), a=24.624(1), b=9.7554(5), c=13.5956(7) Å, β=120.663(1)°, V=2809.2(2) Å3, Z=4, ρ
calc=1.980 g cm−3, μ=1.740 mm−1, T=295 K, structure solution and refinement based on 5239 reflections including Friedel mates (3254 unique) with I
o≥3.0σ(I
o) converged at R=0.0342, R
w=0.0481 and goodness-of-fit=1.85. Data were collected on a Siemens SMART diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073 Å). An empirical absorption correction based on redundant reflections was applied to the data set. The absolute configuration was unambiguously assigned based on the analysis of the Bijovot pairs and the refinement of the Flack parameter. The absence of inversion center in the structure was also confirmed by MISYM. The refinement of Flack parameter for the chosen configuration gave 0.00020(9) with 5239 reflections where F
c(H) and F
c(–H) differ by more than 0.0001. The asymmetric unit contains two Cd2+ ions, two 4,4′-bipy ligands, two SO4

2− anions, and three coordinate and three crystallization water molecules. The metal centers are first linked by the SO4

2− anions to form the one-dimensional arrays of fused 12-membered rings containing three cadmium, three sulfur and six oxygen atoms (see 
). The arrays are drawn together by hydrogen bonding between the coordinate water molecules and the SO4

2− anions from the adjacent net. The two SO4

2− anions are split into μ2- and μ3-bridging ligands. Thus, Cd(1) is coordinated by a μ2-SO4

2−, a μ3-SO4

2− and two cis-H2O molecules while the Cd(2) is linked by a μ2-SO4

2−, two different μ3-SO4

2− anions and a water. The 4,4′-bipy ligands act as ‘posts’ that connect the cadmium centers to form the one-dimensional [Cd2(4,4′-bipy)2(H2O)3]
n


4+ chains. The coordination of both Cd atoms can best be described as slightly distorted octahedral with four O atoms situated in the square plane and two N atoms occupying the axial positions. 
 depicts the coordination environments of the two Cd atoms. Rather than being parallel, these chains run across each other from two different directions. Thus, the compound forms three-dimensional interwoven networks as shown in 
. The most common coordination modes of the SO4

2− ion are monodentate, bidentate and μ2-bridging, while μ3-bridging is much less frequent . The combination of both μ2- and μ3-bridging in the same structure is hitherto unreported. The fact that 1 crystallizes in a noncentrosymmetric space group can perhaps be attributed to this unusual combination of the two different bridging modes for the SO4

2− anion. We have noticed that the use of simple, weaker coordinating anions such as NO3

− and ClO4

− results in centrosymmetric more often than noncentrosymmetric crystal packing.

The compound shows a broad band at \u223c280 nm, an absorption essentially identical to that of free 4,4\u2032-bipyridine, and can be considered optically transparent in the entire visible region. Semi-quantitative measurements of second-harmonic generation for 1 were carried out by the Kurtz\u2013Perry powder method . The sample was ground to ca. 50\u2013200 \u03bcm and irradiated with the 1064 nm fundamental of a Nd-YAG laser. The intensity of the observed 532 nm green light is slightly particle size dependent, and averages ca. 27% of that generated by a sample of potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP) under the same conditions. The characteristic mid-IR bands include a very strong and broad peak at 1111 cm\u22121, a medium doublet at 631 and 617 cm\u22121, attributable to the coordinate SO4\n\n2\u2212 ions, in addition to the aromatic C\u2013C and C\u2013N stretching vibrations at 1592(s), 1530(s), 1491(m) and 1412(s) cm\u22121.

 is a 2D undulated polymeric layer, which crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with Cm space group. The asymmetric coordination unit comprises one Zn(II), one and a half independent 2-eiba ligands, and a half-occupied hydroxide ions. As shown in a, each Zn(II) is coordinated by four O atoms from two 2-eiba ligands and one hydroxide ion, and one N atom from another 2-eiba ligand. The coordination geometry of the Zn center (τ=0.48) can be portrayed as a distorted polyhedron between trigonal bipyramid and square pyramid, where the τ values of the ideal trigonal bipyramid and square pyramid are defined as 1 and 0, respectively . A pair of ZnII centers are interconnected by the μ2-hydroxyl and μ2-COO– bridges to form a [Zn2(COO)(OH)] secondary building unit (SBU), with the Zn⋯Zn separation of 3.292(2) Å. As for the 2-eiba ligands, they show the bridging and terminal linking role to connect the binuclear Zn(II) SBU, respectively. In this way, a grid-like layered coordination net (14.25×14.25Å2), being extended through 2-eiba ligands, is formed (b). This 2D pattern is considerably undulated and of further importance, decorated with the unidentate 2-eiba pendants as side arms at single side. Interestingly, these long prominent arms, with a length of ca.7.824Å between the pyridyl N atom and carboxylate C atom, penetrate into the grids of two adjacent layers to build a 3D polythreading supramolecular architecture with finite components . In fact, each lateral 2-eiba arm goes through two parallel grids and forms a OH⋯N hydrogen bond with the third one (O⋯N=2.759Å, H⋯N=1.91Å, ∠OH⋯N=172°) (c). Thus, if these H-bonding interactions are also taken into account, [Zn2(COO)(OH)] SBUs behave as 6-connected nodes and 2-eiba ligands act as bridges. Then three uniform 3D networks are generated, which are 3-fold interpenetrating (d and e). In view of topological simplification, a single net is isolated and classified as a pcu net .

In the TGA curve of 1 (Fig. S2), the framework keeps intact upon heating to 375\u00b0C and then suffers a sharp weight loss, which does not cease until heating to 800\u00b0C. The TGA curve of 2 shows the first weight loss of 10.23% in the range of 35\u2013240\u00b0C, revealing the removal of three water molecules (calculated: 10.89%). The residue starts to decompose with a sharp weight loss between 350 and 450\u00b0C, and then the slow weight loss does not end until 800\u00b0C. Solid-state fluorescent measurements indicate that excitation of microcrystalline sample of 2-Heiba at 370nm results in the maximum fluorescent emission at 419nm, while those for 1 and 2 appear at 436 and 429nm under the same condition (Fig. S3). By comparing the locations and profiles of their emission peaks, the significant red-shift (\u2206=17nm for 1 and 10nm for 2) and different types of emission profiles of 1 or 2 to 2-Heiba are found. Obviously, these emissions in 1 and 2 are not the intra-ligand \u03c0\u2192\u03c0* transitions of the ligand, but can be properly ascribed to either metal-to-ligand charge transfer (LMCT) or ligand-to-metal charge transfer (MLCT) between the 2-eiba\u2212 and the metal centers in the polymeric networks.

Descriptions of crystal structures

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction shows that the complex 1 crystallizes in the tetragonal space group I4(1)/a and the asymmetric unit consists of one Zn(II) ion, one forth of L1, one PDC and five water molecules. Each Zn atom is six-coordinated in a highly distorted octahedral geometry by four oxygen atoms from two distinct PDC, two nitrogen atoms from one L1 and one PDC, The bond lengths are 2.130(2)\u20132.2393(19)\u00c5 for Zn\u2013O, 2.009(2)\u00c5 for Zn\u2013N, respectively, and the corresponding bond angles around the Zn atom are in the range of 97.94(9)\u2013152.84(8)\u00b0. As shown in \na, the secondary building unit (SBU) of 1 contains a distorted tetrahedral [Zn4(PDC)4] core, in which four ZnII atoms are linked by O-donors from carboxylate groups of PDC with a Zn\u22efZn distance of. 5.055\u00c5. Each tetrahedral linker L1 with the quaternary carbon atom coordinates via its N donor atoms to four [Zn4(PDC)4] cores, resulting in the formation of a 3D framework (b). Better insight into the framework of 1 can be achieved by topology analysis. The tetrahedral linker L1 and [Zn4(PDC)4] core are both viewed as 4-connected nodes, and then the whole networks of 1 can be reduced into a 2-fold interpenetrated sphalerite (ZnS) structure (c). In addition, according to Cheetham\u2019s classification, the structure of 1 falls in 3-D network with M\u2013L\u2013M=0 and inorganic connectivity=3 (I3O0) . Two identical 3-D frameworks interpenetrate each other to fill part of free space in 1, leaving relatively large space for the inclusion of water guest molecules. Calculations using PLATON based on the crystal structure show that the total solvent-accessible volume comprises 40.6% of the crystal volume. Steric hindrance effect of pyridine groups in [Zn4(PDC)4] cores could prevent interpenetration, which are more than that of halide groups in Cu4X4 clusters .

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2(1)/n. In the asymmetry unit of 2, there are one Zn atom, one chelating ligand PDC, one L2 ligand and three water guest molecules. Each Zn ion is in a highly distorted octahedral geometry, coordinated by two O\u2013donors from one PDC, four N-donors from three L2 and one PDC. The Zn\u2013O bond distances vary in the range of 2.159(2)\u22122.197(3)\u00c5, and the Zn\u2013N bond distances vary in the range of 2.028(3)\u20132.224(3)\u00c5, which are all similar to those found in other Zn(II) compounds  and the corresponding bond angles around the Zn atom are in the range of 75.96(12)\u2013175.78(12)\u00b0. Two Zn(II) ions are bridged by the two N-donors from each L2 linker, forming a four-membered [Zn2(L)2] ring, whose internal dimensions is 10.005\u00d79.837\u00c52 (\na). Each Zn(II) ions [Zn2(L)2] ring is linked by one of the other two N-donors of each L2 linker to generate a two-dimensional (2D) layer structure. Meanwhile, each layer interacts with neighboring layers via hydrogen-bond between the water guest molecules and PDC, further extending the 2D layers into a 3D supramolecular framework (b). To further understand the structure of 2, a topological analysis of the network has been performed using Topos by considering both the metal and L2 as topological nodes. Each tetrahedral linker L2 is 3-connected, and then each Zn ion becomes a 2-connected node. Therefore 2 can be reduced into a (2,3)-connected net with 4.8(2) (c). According to Cheetham\u2019s classification, the structure of 2 also belong to 3-D network with M\u2013L\u2013M=0 and inorganic connectivity=3 (I3O0) .

In view of the luminescent properties of d\n10 metal complexes, Accordingly, the emission spectra of 1 and 2 were measured in the solid state at room temperature (see \n). When excitated at 390nm, 1 exhibits one strong emission maximum at 450nm. In contrast, 2 shows an weak fluorescent emission peak at 650nm with an excitation length of 466nm. No obvious photoluminescence was observed for the free L1, L2 and PDC linkers under the same experiment conditions. Thus, the photoluminescence in 1 can be assigned to the emission of ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT). In particular, [Zn4(PDC)4] cores in 1 can make contributions to luminescent properties.

Results and discussion

Crystal structures of complexes 1 and 2\n

Crystal structure of [Zn(INAIP)]\u00b72DMF (1)

The X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that 1 is a 3D porous architecture containing 2D (4, 4) networks pillared by 5-isonicotinamido groups. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of one Zn(II) atom, one INAIP2\u2212 ligand and two non-coordinated DMF molecules. As shown in \na, each Zn(II) atom with square-pyramidal coordination geometry is coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O31, O32C, O51B and O52D) at the basal plane and one pyridyl nitrogen one (N11A) at the apical position. Two Zn(II) atoms are bridged by four carboxylate groups to generate a [Zn2(OCO)4] dinuclear paddle-wheel secondary building units (SBUs). When the coordination of 5-isonicotinamido group is neglected, the SBUs are interlinked together via the bridging INAIP2\u2212 ligands resulting in formation of a metal-carboxylate 2D network with (4, 4) topology regarding the dinuclear SBU as a node (b). The 2D layers are further joined together by 5-isonicotinamido groups via the Zn\u2013N coordination to result in formation of the 3D framework () with one-dimensional (1D) channels along the a-axis as shown in c. The cavities of the 1D channel with an effective pore diameter of 4.5\u00c5 are occupied by DMF molecules. By omitting the DMF molecules, PLATON  calculations revealed that the 3D porous structure of 1 is composed of large voids of 1456.5\u00c53 representing 57.5% per unit cell volume.

Crystal structure of [Zn(INAIP)]\u00b79H2O (2)

When the reaction solvent was changed from DMF used in preparation of 1 to DEF, complex 2 with different structure and topology was obtained. Single crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that compound 2 crystallizes in trigonal space group R\n\u22123m. Each Zn(II) atom in 2 (\na) has similar coordination environment and geometry with that in 1 (a), and there are also [Zn2(OCO)4] dinuclear paddle-wheel SBUs. However, the [Zn2(OCO)4] SBUs in 2 are connected together by INAIP2\u2212 ligands omitting the coordination of 5-isonicotinamido group to give a 2D kagom\u00e9 lattice in the ab plane composed of [Zn2(OCO)2]3 triangles and [Zn2(OCO)2]6 hexagons (b), rather than the 2D (4, 4) net in 1 (b). In addition, in contrast to the presence of DMF in 1, no DEF molecules were detected in 2. The 2D kagom\u00e9 networks are further connected together by the 5-isonicotinamido groups of the INAIP2\u2212 ligands to generate a 3D porous framework (). PLATON  analysis revealed that the 1D channels with effective pore diameter of 4.0 \u00c5 in 2 are composed of large voids of 6959.4\u00c53 (55.7% per unit cell volume) (c). Similar topological analysis was carried out to get insight of the structure of 2. As discussed above, each INAIP2\u2212 ligand and each Zn2 subunit can be regarded as three-connector and six-connecting node, respectively. Thus, the resulting structure of 2 is a binodal (3, 6)-connecting net as shown in d with Point (Schl\u00e4fli) symbol of (42\u00b76)2(44\u00b762\u00b786\u00b7103) calculated by TOPOS .

TGA, powder X-ray diffraction and photoluminescent properties

The results of thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) indicate that compound 1 lost its non-coordinated DMF molecules in the temperature range of 30\u2013190\u00b0C () . The weight loss of 29.75% is consistent with calculated one of 29.48%. After the loss of the DMF molecules, the 3D framework is stable up to 340\u00b0C, followed by further weight loss at high temperature. The end product of decomposition of complex 1 is ZnO with weight percentage 16.33% (calculated: 16.42%). A total weight loss of 31.11% was observed for 2 in the temperature range of 25\u2013275\u00b0C, which can be attributed to the loss of lattice water molecules (calcd 30.97%), and the decomposition of the residue takes place at about 350\u00b0C, the end product of decomposition is also ZnO for 2 with weight percentage of 16.62% (calculated: 15.90%). PXRD was used to check the purity of 1 and 2 () .

The photoluminescent properties of 1, 2 and Na2INAIP were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in , intense emission bands were observed at 465nm (λex

=390nm) for Na2INAIP, 481nm (λex

=390nm) for 1, 468nm (λex

=390nm) for 2. The emissions in 1 and 2 can be attributed to neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) since the Zn(II) ions are in d10 configuration and difficult to oxidize or to reduce. Therefore the emissions observed in 1 and 2 are tentatively assigned to the π − π
* intraligand photoluminescence due to its resemblance to that of Na2INAIP. On the other hand, the emission band intensity for complexes 1 and 2 is increased and decreased, respectively, in comparison to the one of Na2INAIP, which may be ascribed to the quenching effect of water molecules in 2. The results suggest that the complexes 1 and 2 may be good candidate of potential blue-fluorescent materials, since they have high thermal stability and are insoluble in common solvents.

Gas sorption properties

As discussed above, the frameworks 1 and 2 are stable up to 340\u00b0C, thus gas adsorption property of the complexes can be expected. Before gas adsorption tests, activation to remove the guest molecules from the pores by heating under vacuum is a required pretreatment and the as-synthesized crystal samples were heated at an optimized temperature of 140\u00b0C for 20h. To verify whether the framework of 1 can be sustained after the removal of the solvent molecules, PXRD patterns were measured (). The framework of 1 still has crystallinity after removing the solvent molecules, but the PXRD pattern of the activated sample is different from the as-synthesized one which may be attributed to the framework dynamics of 1. The crystalline solid of 1 can be re-generated by immersing the activated sample in 10mL DMF for 12h as indicated by the PXRD measurements () . The results show that the host framework of complex 1 is flexible enough to change its structure depending on the nature of the guest molecules, and the framework transformations are reversible. While complex 2 shows good crystallinity after removing the guest water molecules and the PXRD pattern of the activated sample shifts and becomes broad compared with the as-synthesized one (), therefore, the gas sorption isotherms of 1 and 2 are investigated. The N2 adsorption isotherms for 1 and 2 are shown in \na and b, it can be seen that no N2 uptake was observed at 77K for 1 and 2, hysteresis was observed between the adsorption and desorption curves down to the lowest attainable pressure, which are characteristic for type-H3 sorption . However, significant amounts of CO2 (195K) were adsorbed (c) and both isotherms present typical type-I curves , which is the characteristic of microporous material. The amounts of adsorbed CO2 increase abruptly at the beginning and reach to 60.90cm3 (STP)/g (1.40mmol/g) at 1.0 atom for 1, 43.19cm3 (STP)/g (0.82mmol/g) for 2, approximately 0.48 CO2 and 0.23 CO2 molecules per formula unit were adsorbed for 1 and 2. Fitting the BET equations to the CO2 adsorption isotherm gave estimated surface areas of 119 and 68m2/g for complexes 1 and 2, respectively. The gas sorption isotherms show distinct hysteresis between the adsorption\u2013desorption curves, which must be attributed to the intercrystalline voids . It is noteworthy that no N2 were adsorbed in spite of the channel size larger than the kinetic diameter of N2 (3.64\u00c5), thus, the selective sorption behaviors of CO2 over N2 are attributed to the significant quadrupole moment of CO2 (\u22121.4\u00d710\u221239\nCm2), which induces specific interactions with the host framework . Considering the great current interest of CO2 adsorption/separation, the present work provides nice example of selective sorption behaviors of CO2 over N2 that is not size-controlled, but quadrupole moment induced .

Significantly, the assembly of paddle-wheel clusters as rigid SBUs with polytopic carboxylate linkers could generate rigid porous frameworks with permanent porosity and open functionalized metal sites . As a consequence, Cu2(COO)4 paddle-wheel subunits for different orientations act as square SBUs linking 1D chains to provide a 3D framework with regular 1D parallelogram nanosized channels along the a axis (grid dimensions of 10.55×9.42Å2, calculated from the neighboring Cu(II) atoms) (c). Furthermore, two different kinds of square apertures are present. The first one is polar owing to the effective pore surface occupied mainly by uncoordinate carboxylate oxygen atoms and coordinate aqua molecules, and the twisted benzenyl groups of bptca4
− take up the second hydrophobic channels. When seen from a

×

b plane, the framework structure of 1 is closely compact (), and thus, show noninterpenetrating single network, which depends on the asymmetrical nature of the bptca4
− molecules possessing long molecular backbone to stretch space and large metal clusters laterally to block the interpenetrating aisles. A calculation using platon revealed that the potential total solvent-accessible void space of the framework is 1072.2Å3, corresponding to the 43.5% of the unit cell volume 2466.1Å3
. From the view of topology, the SBUs of dimer [Cu2O2] subunit and tetranuclear [Cu4(μ
3-OH)2] cluster serve as 4-connected and 8-connected nodes, respectively. The bptca4
− ligands show two kinds of coordinated modes, but both of them link four copper-based SBUs, and thus, the organic ligands act as 4-connected nodes. So, the whole 3D framework adopts an unusual tetranodal (4,4,4,8)-connected net with the point symbol of {412.812.104}{43.83}4{46}{86} (d).

Two adjacent Cu1 ions are linked by four bidentate bridging carboxylate groups to afford a paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4 subunit with the Cu–Cu distance of 2.6391(18)Å, being shorter than that of complex 1 (b). Due to the different coordination environment of Cu atoms, the respective paddle-wheel units in 1 and 2, also display some differences, which each bptca4
− ligand of 1 connects only one paddle-wheel cluster and the cation of 2 does two paddle-wheel clusters. The Cu2(COO)4 fragment gets ulteriorly incorporation with four neighboring paddle-wheel clusters via two bidentate bridging carboxylate groups of isophthalate to give a single Cu2(COO)4 paddle-wheel supporting grid structure. These 2D layers are linked in the third direction by folded mononuclear Cu(bptc)2 units, to form a 3D nanoporous framework (c). Similar to 1, the framework accommodates infinite open 1D quadrate channels with 11.20Å caliber (Cu…Cu distance). Meanwhile, the closely arrangement of the components on the a

×

b or a

×

c plane suggests the noninterpenetrating features of the final framework (). The potential solvent-accessible volume of 2 is 2129.5Å3, which corresponds to 42.7% of unit cell volume 4991.0Å3 according to the platon calculations . From the viewpoint of the network topology, 2 possesses 3D (4,4)-connected binodal frameworks with {42.84} PtS-type topology, by considering each mononuclear Cu(bptca)2 and paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4 clusters as 4-connected nodes (d).

Complexes 1 and 2 are air-stable and can retain the crystalline integrity at ambient conditions. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) show that 1 and 2 have onset weight losses within the temperature range of 125\u2013240\u00b0C and 110\u2013205\u00b0C, respectively (\n). The first steps of TGA curves correspond to the release of the unknown disordered solvent molecules. Almost without pause, the host MOFs begin to decompose continuously until the final products CuO obtained. Consequently, the final MOFs exhibit ordinary thermal stability, which can be attributed to the anion nature of the frameworks strengthened by charge-balancing guest cations.
